title: 109_hr4334
content:
The "Hurricane Wilma Taxpayer Relief Act of 2005" includes special rules for the use of retirement funds for relief related to Hurricane Wilma, such as tax-favored withdrawals, recontributions for home purchases canceled due to the hurricane, loans from qualified plans, and provisions for plan amendments. Additionally, the Act includes charitable giving incentives. The "Hurricane Wilma Taxpayer Relief Act of 2005" includes provisions for charitable contributions, standard mileage rate increase for charitable use of vehicles, and tax relief for personal casualty losses. It also addresses the suspension of certain limitations and extension of replacement period for nonrecognition of gain for property in the Hurricane Wilma disaster area. The "Hurricane Wilma Taxpayer Relief Act of 2005" defines terms related to disaster areas and retirement fund withdrawals for Hurricane Wilma relief. The "Hurricane Wilma Taxpayer Relief Act of 2005" exempts qualified Hurricane Wilma distributions from Section 72(t) of the Internal Revenue Code. There is a $100,000 limit on the total amount of qualified Hurricane Wilma distributions an individual can receive in a taxable year. This limit is calculated by subtracting the total distributions received in prior years and any qualified Hurricane Katrina distributions from $100,000. The "Hurricane Wilma Taxpayer Relief Act of 2005" allows qualified Hurricane Wilma distributions to be exempt from Section 72(t) of the Internal Revenue Code. There is a $100,000 limit on the total amount of such distributions an individual can receive in a taxable year, calculated by subtracting prior year distributions and any qualified Hurricane Katrina distributions. The "Hurricane Wilma Taxpayer Relief Act of 2005" exempts qualified distributions from Section 72(t) of the Internal Revenue Code. Individuals can receive up to $100,000 in distributions, excluding prior year distributions and qualified Hurricane Katrina distributions. A controlled group refers to a single employer under specific sections of the Code. Individuals can repay distributions to an eligible retirement plan within 3 years. The Hurricane Wilma Taxpayer Relief Act of 2005 allows for qualified distributions from eligible retirement plans under specific sections of the Internal Revenue Code. Repayments of distributions can be made to eligible retirement plans within 3 years, treating the distribution as an eligible rollover distribution. The Hurricane Wilma Taxpayer Relief Act of 2005 permits qualified distributions from eligible retirement plans. Repayments for distributions from IRAs can be made within 60 days in a trustee-to-trustee transfer. The Hurricane Wilma Taxpayer Relief Act of 2005 allows qualified distributions from eligible retirement plans for individuals affected by Hurricane Wilma in a specified time frame. Repayments for distributions from IRAs can be made within 60 days in a trustee-to-trustee transfer. The Hurricane Wilma Taxpayer Relief Act of 2005 allows qualified distributions from eligible retirement plans for individuals affected by Hurricane Wilma. Repayments for distributions from IRAs can be made within 60 days in a trustee-to-trustee transfer. Special rules apply for the inclusion of income over a 3-taxable year period and exemptions from certain distribution and withholding rules. The Hurricane Wilma Taxpayer Relief Act of 2005 allows qualified distributions from eligible retirement plans for individuals affected by Hurricane Wilma to meet specific requirements of the Internal Revenue Code. SEC. 102. RECONTRIBUTIONS OF WITHDRAWALS FOR HOME PURCHASES CANCELLED DUE TO HURRICANE WILMA. During a specified period, individuals who received a qualified distribution can make contributions to an eligible retirement plan, not exceeding the distribution amount. Rules similar to repayment rules apply. During a specified period, individuals who received a qualified distribution can make contributions to an eligible retirement plan, not exceeding the distribution amount. This applies to distributions related to financial hardship in the Hurricane Wilma disaster area between February 28, 2005, and October 24, 2005, for the purchase or construction of a principal residence. Coordination with contributions due to Hurricane Katrina is also considered. Under the Act of 2005, contributions for a distribution are reduced by any contributions under section 102 of the Act. SEC. 103. Loans from qualified plans for relief related to Hurricane Wilma. Increase in loan limits for qualified individuals from qualified employer plans after the enactment of the Act until January 1, 2007. The limit is raised to $100,000 from $50,000, and the calculation for the loan amount is based on the present value of the employee's accrued benefit. Additionally, a delay in repayment is allowed for qualified individuals with outstanding loans from qualified employer plans after October 23, 2005. The employer plan loan repayment due date is delayed for 1 year for repayments between October 23, 2005, and December 31, 2006. Subsequent repayments will adjust for the delay and accrued interest. The 5-year period and loan term calculation exclude the delayed period. A qualified individual is defined as someone with a principal place of employment. A "qualified individual" is someone whose main residence was in the Hurricane Wilma disaster area on October 23, 2005, and suffered an economic loss due to the hurricane. SEC. 104. PROVISIONS RELATING TO PLAN AMENDMENTS. This section applies to any plan or annuity contract amendment made under specific conditions by a certain date. This section applies to plan or annuity contract amendments made under specific conditions by a certain date, with a provision for governmental plans to apply a 2-year delay. The plan or contract amendment is operated retroactively from the date it is adopted. TITLE II--CHARITABLE GIVING INCENTIVES

SEC. 201. TEMPORARY SUSPENSION OF LIMITATIONS ON CHARITABLE CONTRIBUTIONS. A charitable contribution paid by a corporation for Hurricane Wilma relief efforts will be treated as if it were for Hurricane Katrina relief efforts.

SEC. 202. INCREASE IN STANDARD MILEAGE RATE FOR CHARITABLE USE OF VEHICLES. SEC. 202. INCREASE IN STANDARD MILEAGE RATE FOR CHARITABLE USE OF VEHICLES. The standard mileage rate for vehicles used for Hurricane Wilma relief from October 23, 2005, to December 31, 2006, will be 70 percent of the standard rate under section 162(a) of the Internal Revenue Code. Any increase will be rounded to the next highest cent. For taxable years ending on or after October 23, 2005, gross income of an individual does not include reimbursement of operating expenses for using a passenger automobile for Hurricane Wilma relief provided by a qualifying organization. The expenses must be deductible under the Internal Revenue Code, using the standard business mileage rate and treating the individual as an employee of a non-qualifying organization. The text chunk discusses the exclusion of expenses from gross income for services provided to a qualifying organization. Deductions or credits are not allowed for these expenses under any other provision of the Internal Revenue Code. TITLE III--ADDITIONAL TAX RELIEF PROVISIONS

SEC. 301. SUSPENSION OF LIMITATIONS ON PERSONAL CASUALTY LOSSES for losses in Hurricane Wilma disaster area after October 23, 2005, due to Hurricane Wilma.

SEC. 302. EXTENSION OF REPLACEMENT PERIOD FOR NONRECOGNITION OF GAIN for property in Hurricane Wilma disaster area. Clause (i) of section 1033(a)(2)(B) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to substitute "5 years" for "2 years" for property in the Hurricane Wilma disaster area compulsorily converted after October 23, 2005, due to Hurricane Wilma, if most of the replacement property's use is in that area. This provision is designated as an emergency requirement under section 402 of H. Con. Res. 95 (109th Congress).
